title: Malaria 2000-2017
text:
0.1 Presentation Recording
cat("Watch the Presentation: https://youtu.be/h7a-UFw0gOk")

Watch the Presentation: https://youtu.be/h7a-UFw0gOk
Malaria is a life-threatening disease which continues to claim hundreds of thousands of lives each year, particularly in developing regions with limited access to healthcare infrastructure. Transmitted through the bite of infected female Anopheles mosquitoes, malaria is both a biological and social challenge that intersects with issues of poverty, geography, and political will. This report presents an in-depth data-driven exploration of malaria cases and deaths from 2000 to 2017. It aims to uncover global and regional patterns, analyze changes over time, and offer insights into how the fight against malaria has progressed in different parts of the world.
The central question guiding this study is: How have global malaria cases and death rates evolved over time, and how do these trends vary across WHO regions and countries between 2000 and 2017? To investigate this, we used a dataset provided by the World Health Organization that includes annual country-level records of reported malaria cases and deaths, categorized by WHO region. We employed both static and animated visualizations to reveal temporal and spatial patterns in the data. This approach enables us to not only assess long-term global trends but also to highlight persistent regional disparities and emerging areas of concern.

title: Malaria 2000-2017
text:
0.2 What is the overall trend?

library(ggplot2)
library(tidyverse)
library(dplyr)

file.exists("data/archive 2/estimated_numbers.csv")

[1] TRUE

estimated_numbers <- read.csv("data/archive 2/estimated_numbers.csv") 
incidence <-read.csv("data/archive 2/incidence_per_1000_pop_at_risk.csv")
reported <-read.csv("data/archive 2/reported_numbers.csv") 

reported$Year <- as.factor(reported$Year)
reported %>%
  group_by(Year) %>%
  summarize(total_cases = sum(No..of.cases, na.rm = TRUE)) %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = Year, y = total_cases, group = 1)) +
  geom_line() +
  geom_point() +
  labs(title = "Total Reported Malaria Cases Over Time",
       x = "Year",
       y = "Total Cases") +
  theme_minimal()







Between 2000 and 2007, the number of reported malaria cases globally remained relatively stableâ€”hovering around 10 to 15 million per year. But starting around 2008, there is a dramatic shift. As shown in this plot, reported cases begin to rise sharply, reaching over 125 million by 2017. This pattern appears to contradict the common belief that malaria is steadily declining worldwide.
However, the increase may reflect expanded diagnostic capacity and improved surveillance, rather than an actual surge in transmission. Many countries introduced more comprehensive reporting systems in the 2010s, which likely resulted in a higher number of cases being documented. In other words, we might be seeing more malaria not because the situation is worsening, but because weâ€™re getting better at counting it.

title: Malaria 2000-2017
text:
0.3 Are people dying from it?

reported %>% 
  drop_na(No..of.deaths) %>% 
  mutate(Year = as.factor(Year)) %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = Year, y = No..of.deaths)) +
  geom_boxplot(fill = "#56B4E9", alpha = 0.7) +
  labs(title = "Distribution of Reported Malaria Deaths by Year (Global)",
       y = "Number of Deaths", x = "Year") +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1))







To understand whether more cases led to more deaths, we can turn to the second chart: a boxplot showing the distribution of reported malaria deaths by country each year. Despite the sharp increase in reported cases, the distribution of deaths remains relatively wide but doesnâ€™t follow the same sharp upward trajectory. Most countries consistently report relatively low death numbers, while a small number continue to report high fatalities each yearâ€”sometimes over 50,000.
This suggests that while malaria remains widespread, it is becoming less deadly overall, possibly due to wider access to treatment and earlier diagnosis. However, the range between countries is still large. Some countries have clearly succeeded in reducing malaria mortality, while others continue to struggle.

title: Malaria 2000-2017
text:
0.4 Where are most people dying?

reported %>% 
  drop_na(No..of.deaths) %>% 
  mutate(Year = as.factor(Year)) %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = Year, y = No..of.deaths)) +
  geom_point(color = "#D55E00", alpha = 0.7) +
  labs(title = "Reported Malaria Deaths Over Time by WHO Region",
       y = "Number of Deaths", x = "Year") +
  facet_wrap(~ WHO.Region, scales = "free") +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold"),
        axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1))








# ğŸ“ˆ Line graph of deaths over time by WHO Region
reported %>% 
  drop_na(No..of.deaths) %>% 
  group_by(WHO.Region, Year) %>%  # <-- group by region and year
  summarize(total_deaths = sum(No..of.deaths, na.rm = TRUE)) %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = Year, y = total_deaths, color = WHO.Region, group = WHO.Region)) +
  geom_line(size = 1.2) +
  geom_point(size = 2) +
  labs(title = "Reported Malaria Deaths Over Time by WHO Region",
       x = "Year",
       y = "Total Reported Deaths",
       color = "WHO Region") +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold"),
        axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1))

`summarise()` has grouped output by 'WHO.Region'. You can override using the
`.groups` argument.


Warning: Using `size` aesthetic for lines was deprecated in ggplot2 3.4.0.
â„¹ Please use `linewidth` instead.








The next two charts break down death patterns by WHO regionâ€”first using individual dot plots for each region, then summarizing total regional deaths over time. The pattern here is unmistakable: Africa accounts for the vast majority of global malaria deaths, and this has remained true throughout the entire 2000â€“2017 period.
In contrast, other regions such as Europe and the Americas report very low death counts, often close to zero. Even South-East Asia, once a major malaria hotspot, shows a steady decline in mortality across the 18 years. These trends reveal a stark inequality in the global burden of malaria. While some regions are approaching elimination, othersâ€”especially in sub-Saharan Africaâ€”continue to face high and persistent mortality.

title: Malaria 2000-2017
text:
0.5 Letâ€™s take a closer look

malaria_clean <- reported %>%
  select(Country, Year, `No..of.cases`) %>%
  rename(
    country = Country,
    year = Year,
    cases = `No..of.cases`
  )


library(plotly)


Attaching package: 'plotly'


The following object is masked from 'package:ggplot2':

    last_plot


The following object is masked from 'package:stats':

    filter


The following object is masked from 'package:graphics':

    layout

fig <- plot_ly(
  data = malaria_clean,
  locations = ~country,
  locationmode = 'country names',
  z = ~cases,
  text = ~paste(country, "<br>Cases:", cases),
  type = 'choropleth',
  frame = ~year,
  colorscale = 'Reds',
  marker = list(line = list(color = "gray", width = 0.5))
)

fig <- fig %>%
  layout(
    title = "Reported Malaria Cases Over Time",
   geo = list(showframe = FALSE,
               showcoastlines = FALSE,
               showcountries = TRUE,
               countrycolor = "gray",
               projection = list(type = "equirectangular"),
               bgcolor = "white",
               landcolor = "white")
  )

fig

Warning: Ignoring 234 observations







# Install and load countrycode package if not already installed
if (!require(countrycode)) {
  install.packages("countrycode")
}

Loading required package: countrycode

library(countrycode)

library(tidyverse)
library(plotly)

# Example: cleaning reported data
reported_clean_2 <- reported %>%
  mutate(
    country = countrycode(Country, origin = "country.name", destination = "iso3c")
    # year = as.integer(Year),
    # deaths = as.numeric(No..of.deaths)
  ) %>%
  filter(!is.na(country)
         # !is.na(year),
         # !is.na(deaths)
  )

# Create animated choropleth plot
fig <- plot_ly(
  data = reported_clean_2,
  type = "choropleth",
  locations = ~country,         # ISO3 codes
  z = ~No..of.deaths,           # Coloring by deaths
  frame = ~Year,                # Animation frame by year
  colorscale = "Reds",
  text = ~paste(Country, "<br>Deaths:", No..of.deaths),
  colorbar = list(title = "Deaths"),
  reversescale = FALSE
)

fig <- fig %>%
  layout(
    title = "Reported Deaths by Country Over Time",
    geo = list(
      showframe = FALSE,
      showcoastlines = FALSE,
      showcountries = TRUE,
      countrycolor = "gray",
      projection =list(type = "equirectangular"),
      bgcolor = "white",
      landcolor = "white"
    )
  )

fig

Warning: Ignoring 269 observations







malaria_clean <- reported %>%
  select(Country, Year, `No..of.cases`, `No..of.deaths`) %>%
  rename(
    country = Country,
    year = Year,
    cases = `No..of.cases`,
    deaths = `No..of.deaths`
  )


fig <- plot_ly() %>%
  add_trace(
    data = malaria_clean,
    type = "choropleth",
    locations = ~country,
    locationmode = "country names",
    z = ~cases,
    frame = ~year,
    colorscale = "Blues",
    reversescale = TRUE,
    text = ~paste("Country:", country,
                  "<br>Total Cases:", format(cases, big.mark = ","),
                  "<br>Deaths:", format(deaths, big.mark = ",")),
    hoverinfo = "text",
    colorbar = list(title = "Total Cases"),
    marker = list(line = list(color = "white", width = 0.5))
  ) %>%
  

  add_trace(
    data = malaria_clean,
    type = "scattergeo",
    locations = ~country,
    locationmode = "country names",
    frame = ~year,
    marker = list(
      size = ~sqrt(deaths) * 0.25,
      color = 'red',
      opacity = 0.6,
      line = list(width = 0)
    ),
    hoverinfo = "none",
    showlegend = FALSE
  ) %>%
  
  layout(
    title = "Global Malaria Cases and Deaths from 2000 to 2017",
    geo = list(
      showframe = FALSE,
      showcountries = TRUE,
      showcoastlines = FALSE,
      countrycolor = "grey",
      landcolor = "lightgrey",
      projection = list(type = "equirectangular"),
      bgcolor = "white"
    )
  )

fig

Warning: Ignoring 234 observations


No scattergeo mode specifed:
  Setting the mode to markers
  Read more about this attribute -> https://plotly.com/r/reference/#scatter-mode






So far, weâ€™ve looked at overall trends and regional disparities. But what does the malaria burden look like at the country level? Using interactive Plotly maps, we can track changes over time and visualize not just where malaria is spreading, but where itâ€™s killing.
The first map focuses on reported malaria cases from 2000 to 2017. Here, countries like India, Brazil, and Indonesia appear prominently, with India consistently reporting over 2 million cases per year. Interestingly, many African countries show little or no shading in early yearsâ€”not because malaria wasnâ€™t present, but because surveillance systems were still developing. Over time, these countries become more visible, reinforcing the idea that part of the global increase in reported cases may be due to improved detection rather than worsening transmission.
The second map shows malaria-related deaths, and the picture shifts dramatically. South Asian and South American countries that previously looked severe now appear much lighter. Meanwhile, central and western African countries dominate the death map, with the darkest shades consistently appearing in places like Nigeria and the Democratic Republic of Congo. This highlights a critical distinction: many regions have high numbers of infections, but only some face the compounded burden of both high infection and high mortality, often due to weaker healthcare systems. The final map puts everything together. Background shading represents case counts, while red circles denote the number of deaths. Countries like India are dark blue but have small red circlesâ€”indicating effective treatment and relatively low fatality rates. In contrast, the large red circles clustered across central Africa tell a different story: many of these countries are not only struggling with high malaria transmission, but also lack the infrastructure to prevent deaths.
These maps donâ€™t just tell us where malaria is. They show us where it is deadliest. And thatâ€™s where the worldâ€™s attention and resources need to stay focused.

title: Malaria 2000-2017
section: 0.6 Where do we go from here?
text:
0.6 Where do we go from here?
The data makes one thing clear: malaria is not a disease of the pastâ€”it is an ongoing global emergency, and one that is still evolving. While surveillance and treatment have improved in many countries, millions of people remain at risk, and tens of thousands still die every year from a preventable and treatable illness.
As we move forward, the goal is not just to reduce numbers on a chart, but to close the global gap in prevention and care. That means targeted investment in the regions that need it most, continued innovation in diagnostics and treatment, and stronger international cooperation. Data like this helps us understand where the problems are. What happens next depends on whether we act on it.

title: 2Â  Feride K
text:
https://www.atlassian.com/blog/teamwork/the-importance-of-teamwork

2.0.1 Summary: The Importance of Teamwork (As Proven by Science)
Research shows that teamwork isnâ€™t just good for business, it boosts innovation, happiness, personal growth, and resilience across the board. With the rise of virtual work, collaboration has become even more essential.
Teamwork leads to:

Better problem-solving: Groups outperform individuals by combining skills and perspectives.
More innovation: Diverse teams unlock creativity and breakthrough ideas.
Happier employees: Honest, respectful teams boost emotional well-being and productivity.
Personal growth: Feedback and cross-training within teams help individuals improve and learn about themselves.
Reduced burnout: Sharing work and emotional support among teammates protects against stress.
Opportunities for growth: Teams solve complex problems better because no one person can know everything.
Higher productivity: Peer respect is a stronger motivator than manager approval.
Smarter risk-taking: Team support encourages bold, innovative ideas, especially in smaller groups.
Fewer mistakes: Supportive, low-stress teams make fewer errors.
Increased creativity: Open communication and trust allow new ideas to flourish.
Ultimately, teamwork creates stronger individuals, better companies, and smarter solutions to todayâ€™s complex challenges.

title: 3Â  Amy Y
text:
3.1 Effective Teamwork
Teamwork is a foundational component of successful organizations, yet it requires more than just collaborationâ€”it calls for a strong set of interpersonal and problem-solving skills. According to SkillPathâ€™s article â€œEffective Teamwork: 8 Simple Characteristics of a Great Teamâ€ (2023), high-functioning teams share several defining traits:
Source: SkillPath Staff. â€œEffective Teamwork: 8 Simple Characteristics of a Great Team.â€ SkillPath, Sep.Â 20, 2023. https://skillpath.com/blog/effective-teamwork

title: 3Â  Amy Y
text:
Dependence Team members recognize their mutual reliance, focusing on shared and individual goals without undermining others for personal gain.
Trust Open, trusting environments allow members to express concerns, ask questions, and offer creative solutions without fear.
Ownership Members take personal responsibility and feel invested in the teamâ€™s outcomes, striving for collective rather than individual success.
Individual Strengths Effective teams leverage the unique knowledge and skills of each member, contributing meaningfully to shared objectives.
Open Communication Continuous, clear communication ensures mutual understanding and reinforces a culture of transparency.
Ongoing Growth Strong teams support professional development, encouraging members to learn, experiment, and growâ€”even through mistakes.
Group Decision-Making Decisions are made collaboratively, valuing each personâ€™s perspective while accepting that the leader may decide when consensus cannot be reached.
Strong Conflict Resolution Healthy teams resolve disagreements promptly and constructively, maintaining open lines of communication throughout.

title: 4Â  Aisling L
text:
https://hr.berkeley.edu/hr-network/central-guide-managing-hr/managing-hr/interaction/team-building/steps

4.0.1 Steps to building an effective team
The first rule of team building is an obvious one: to lead a team effectively, you must first establish your leadership with each team member. Remember that the most effective team leaders build their relationships of trust and loyalty, rather than fear or the power of their positions.

Consider each employeeâ€™s ideas as valuable. Remember that there is no such thing as a stupid idea.
Be aware of employeesâ€™ unspoken feelings. Set an example to team members by being open with employees and sensitive to their moods and feelings.
Act as a harmonizing influence. Look for chances to mediate and resolve minor disputes; point continually toward the teamâ€™s higher goals.
Be clear when communicating. Be careful to clarify directives.
Encourage trust and cooperation among employees on your team. Remember that the relationships team members establish among themselves are every bit as important as those you establish with them. As the team begins to take shape, pay close attention to the ways in which team members work together and take steps to improve communication, cooperation, trust, and respect in those relationships.
Encourage team members to share information. Emphasize the importance of each team memberâ€™s contribution and demonstrate how all of their jobs operate together to move the entire team closer to its goal. Delegate problem-solving tasks to the team. Let the team work on creative solutions together.
Facilitate communication. Remember that communication is the single most important factor in successful teamwork. Facilitating communication does not mean holding meetings all the time. Instead it means setting an example by remaining open to suggestions and concerns, by asking questions and offering help, and by doing everything you can to avoid confusion in your own communication.
Establish team values and goals; evaluate team performance. Be sure to talk with members about the progress they are making toward established goals so that employees get a sense both of their success and of the challenges that lie ahead. Address teamwork in performance standards.
Make sure that you have a clear idea of what you need to accomplish.
Use consensus. Set objectives, solve problems, and plan for action. While it takes much longer to establish consensus, this method ultimately provides better decisions and greater productivity because it secures every employeeâ€™s commitment to all phases of the work.
Set ground rules for the team. These are the norms that you and the team establish to ensure efficiency and success. They can be simple directives (Team members are to be punctual for meetings) or general guidelines (Every team member has the right to offer ideas and suggestions), but you should make sure that the team creates these ground rules by consensus and commits to them, both as a group and as individuals.

title: 5Â  Zora S
text:
https://skillpath.com/blog/effective-teamwork

Clear Communication: Team members must communicate openly and ensure everyone feels heard.
Trust: Building trust among members is critical for strong collaboration.
Clear Goals: Teams need well-defined goals so everyone moves in the same direction.
Good Leadership: A strong leader helps guide the team, solve conflicts, and keep motivation high.
Flexibility: Successful teams are able to adapt quickly to changes and unexpected challenges.
Continuous Improvement: Teams should always look for ways to improve their processes and performance.

text:

# Load necessary libraries
library(tidyverse)
library(ggplot2)
library(data.table)

# Set data directory
dir1 <- "../input/malaria-dataset/"

# Load datasets
estimated_numbers <- read.csv("../../data/archive 2/estimated_numbers.csv", stringsAsFactors = FALSE)
incidence <- read.csv("../../data/archive 2/incidence_per_1000_pop_at_risk.csv", stringsAsFactors = FALSE)
reported <- read.csv("../../data/archive 2/reported_numbers.csv", stringsAsFactors = FALSE)

# Merge reported and incidence datasets
data <- reported %>% 
  left_join(incidence, by = c("Country", "Year", "WHO.Region")) %>% 
  rename("No.of.cases" = "No..of.cases.x",
         "No.of.cases.per.1000.pop.at.risk" = "No..of.cases.y")

# Set plot size for better readability
options(repr.plot.width = 14, repr.plot.height = 10)

# Boxplot of global deaths by year (non-faceted)
reported %>% 
  drop_na(No..of.deaths) %>% 
  mutate(Year = as.factor(Year)) %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = Year, y = No..of.deaths)) +
  geom_boxplot(fill = "#56B4E9", alpha = 0.7) +
  labs(title = "Distribution of Reported Malaria Deaths by Year (Global)",
       y = "Number of Deaths", x = "Year") +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1))






# ğŸŸ  Scatter plot of deaths over time, faceted by WHO Region
reported %>% 
  drop_na(No..of.deaths) %>% 
  mutate(Year = as.factor(Year)) %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = Year, y = No..of.deaths)) +
  geom_point(color = "#D55E00", alpha = 0.7) +
  labs(title = "Reported Malaria Deaths Over Time by WHO Region",
       y = "Number of Deaths", x = "Year") +
  facet_wrap(~ WHO.Region, scales = "free") +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold"),
        axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1))







general trends- what is going on in this region

incidence <- read.csv("../../data/archive 2/incidence_per_1000_pop_at_risk.csv", stringsAsFactors = FALSE)
reported <- read.csv("../../data/archive 2/reported_numbers.csv", stringsAsFactors = FALSE)

# Merge reported and incidence datasets

  left_join(incidence, by = c("Country", "Year", "WHO.Region")) %>%

  summarize(total_deaths = sum(No..of.deaths, na.rm = TRUE)) %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = Year, y = total_deaths, color = WHO.Region, group = WHO.Region)) +
  geom_line(size = 1.2) +

       x = "Year",

title: 7Â  Amy Y
text:

library(tidyverse)

library(sf)

Linking to GEOS 3.11.0, GDAL 3.5.3, PROJ 9.1.0; sf_use_s2() is TRUE

library(rnaturalearth)

estimated_numbers <- read.csv("../../data/archive 2/estimated_numbers.csv") 
incidence <-read.csv("../../data/archive 2/incidence_per_1000_pop_at_risk.csv")
reported <-read.csv("../../data/archive 2/reported_numbers.csv") #use this one

world <- rnaturalearth::ne_countries(scale = "medium", returnclass = "sf")


dim(reported)

[1] 1944    5

reported_clean <- reported %>%
  rename(deaths = No..of.deaths)   

map_data <- world %>%
  left_join(reported_clean, by = c("name" = "Country"))


ggplot(map_data) +
  geom_sf(aes(fill = deaths), color = "white", size = 0.1) +
  scale_fill_viridis_c(option = "plasma", trans = "log10") +
  facet_wrap(~ Year) +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(
    title = "Reported Deaths by Country Over Time",
    fill = "Deaths (log scale)"
  )

Warning in scale_fill_viridis_c(option = "plasma", trans = "log10"): log-10
transformation introduced infinite values.








##RQ: reported deaths vs time vs country

library(dplyr)
library(countrycode)


# Example: cleaning reported data
# Replace 'country', 'year', and 'deaths' with your real column names
reported_clean_2 <- reported %>%
  mutate(
    country = countrycode(Country, origin = "country.name", destination = "iso3c"),
  #  year = as.integer(Year),
 #   deaths = as.numeric(No..of.deaths)
  ) %>%
  filter(!is.na(country), 
        # !is.na(year), 
       #  !is.na(deaths)
         )

  data = reported_clean_2,
  type = "choropleth",
  locations = ~country,
  z = ~No..of.deaths,
  frame = ~Year,
  colorscale = "Reds",

  colorbar = list(title = "Deaths"),
  reversescale = FALSE
)

  layout(
    title = "Reported Deaths by Country Over Time",
    geo = list(showframe = FALSE,
               showcoastlines = FALSE,

fig

Warning: Ignoring 269 observations












Caption



This interactice choropleth map shows the number of reported deaths of malaria by countries from 2000 to 2017. Countries shaded in deeper red tones indicate higher death counts, while countries in paler or base colors report fewer or no deaths in a given year. All the coutries appearing with the base color are included in the dataset.


##RQ: total case vs deaths vs time vs country

malaria_clean <- reported %>%
  select(Country, Year, `No..of.cases`) %>%
  rename(
    country = Country,
    year = Year,
    cases = `No..of.cases`
  )


library(plotly)
fig <- plot_ly(
  data = malaria_clean,
  locations = ~country,
  locationmode = 'country names',
  z = ~cases,
  text = ~paste(country, "<br>Cases:", cases),
  type = 'choropleth',
  frame = ~year,
  colorscale = 'Reds',
  marker = list(line = list(color = "gray", width = 0.5))
)

fig <- fig %>%
  layout(
    title = "Estimated Malaria Cases Over Time (Median)",
    geo = list(
      showframe = FALSE,
      showcoastlines = FALSE
    ),
    coloraxis = list(colorbar = list(title = "Cases"))
  )

fig <- fig %>%
  layout(
    title = "Estimated Malaria Cases and Deaths Over Time (Median)",
    geo = list(
      showframe = FALSE,
      showcoastlines = FALSE,
      showcountries = TRUE,
               countrycolor = "gray",
               projection = list(type = "equirectangular"),
               bgcolor = "white",
               landcolor = "white"
    ),
    coloraxis = list(
      colorbar = list(title = "Cases")
    )
  )


fig

Warning: Ignoring 234 observations







8 Explanation
This map visualizes the number of reported malaria-related deaths by country from the year 2000 to 2017. Each country is colored on a gradient from light to dark red, where darker shades indicate a higher number of deaths. As the animation progresses through time, we can observe how the burden of malaria shifts across regions. Notably, countries in sub-Saharan Africaâ€”especially the Democratic Republic of Congo and Nigeriaâ€”consistently show the darkest shades, highlighting their persistent struggle with malaria mortality. This temporal and spatial visualization helps emphasize where intervention efforts have been or still need to be concentrated.

malaria_clean <- reported %>%
  select(Country, Year, `No..of.cases`, `No..of.deaths`) %>%
  rename(
    country = Country,
    year = Year,
    cases = `No..of.cases`,
    deaths = `No..of.deaths`
  )


fig <- plot_ly() %>%
  add_trace(
    data = malaria_clean,
    type = "choropleth",
    locations = ~country,
    locationmode = "country names",
    z = ~cases,
    frame = ~year,
    colorscale = "Blues",
    reversescale = TRUE,
    text = ~paste("Country:", country,
                  "<br>Total Cases:", format(cases, big.mark = ","),
                  "<br>Deaths:", format(deaths, big.mark = ",")),
    hoverinfo = "text",
    colorbar = list(title = "Total Cases"),
    marker = list(line = list(color = "white", width = 0.5))
  ) %>%
  

  add_trace(
    data = malaria_clean,
    type = "scattergeo",
    locations = ~country,
    locationmode = "country names",
    frame = ~year,
    marker = list(
      size = ~sqrt(deaths) * 0.25,
      color = 'red',
      opacity = 0.6,
      line = list(width = 0)
    ),
    hoverinfo = "none",
    showlegend = FALSE
  ) %>%
  
  layout(
    title = "Global Malaria Cases and Deaths from 2000 to 2017",
    geo = list(
      showframe = FALSE,
      showcountries = TRUE,
      showcoastlines = FALSE,
      countrycolor = "grey",
      landcolor = "lightgrey",
      projection = list(type = "equirectangular"),
      bgcolor = "white"
    )
  )

fig

Warning: Ignoring 234 observations


No scattergeo mode specifed:
  Setting the mode to markers
  Read more about this attribute -> https://plotly.com/r/reference/#scatter-mode







9 Explanation
This interactive map illustrates global malaria cases and deaths from the year 2000 to 2017. The background color of each country represents the total number of malaria cases, using a blue gradientâ€”darker blue indicates higher case counts. Overlaying the map, we use red circles to represent the number of reported deaths. The larger the circle, the higher the death toll.
This dual-encoded map lets us compare both the prevalence of malaria and its mortality burden at once. For instance, you can see that many central and western African countries not only have dark blue shadingâ€”indicating high case numbersâ€”but also large red circles, revealing significant death counts. Meanwhile, other regions may have lighter shades with smaller circles, showing lower disease burden.
Overall, this visualization helps us track the geographic and temporal patterns of malaria, highlighting where the disease hits hardest and where public health efforts should be prioritized.

Linking to GEOS 3.11.0, GDAL 3.5.3, PROJ 9.1.0; sf_use_s2() is TRUE

library(rnaturalearth)

estimated_numbers <- read.csv("../../data/archive 2/estimated_numbers.csv") 
incidence <-read.csv("../../data/archive 2/incidence_per_1000_pop_at_risk.csv")
reported <-read.csv("../../data/archive 2/reported_numbers.csv")


reported$Year <- as.factor(reported$Year)
reported %>%
  group_by(Year) %>%
  summarize(total_cases = sum(No..of.cases, na.rm = TRUE)) %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = Year, y = total_cases, group = 1)) +
  geom_line() +
  geom_point() +
  labs(title = "Total Reported Malaria Cases Over Time",
       x = "Year",
       y = "Total Cases") +
  theme_minimal()

title: Appendix A â€” Proposal
text:
Your proposal will go here.

A.0.1 Number of Malaria Cases from 2010

Amy Yang, Riley Karatas, Aisling Li, Zora Shi
Malaria is a life-threatening disease caused by parasites that are transmitted to people through the bites of infected female Anopheles mosquitoes. Due to the significance of the cause we will be analyzing malaria cases from 2010 to 2017 in terms of global distribution, as well as changes in case numbers and death rate.

title: Appendix B â€” Case Study
text:
Your case study will go here.

Germanyâ€™s Multiparty System Unlike the U.S. two-party system, Germanyâ€™s Bundestag includes multiple significant parties. The chart shows that no party typically wins a majority, which necessitates coalition governments. CDU/CSU (center-right) and SPD (center-left) are the largest parties but have seen declining shares over time, making smaller parties like the Greens, FDP, and AfD increasingly relevant in coalition-building.
Party Ideology Distribution The ideological spectrum chart maps German parties from left to right. The Left (far-left) and AfD (far-right) anchor the extremes. SPD, Greens, and CDU/CSU are more centrist, though CDU leans conservative. The chart reveals that German political ideology is more left-leaning overall than U.S. counterparts â€” even the CDU is not as far right as American Republicans.
Voter Base by Region (East vs.Â West) A geographic map shows stark regional divides: The Left dominates in the former East Germany. CDU and SPD perform better in the wealthier West. AfD shows stronger support in economically disadvantaged eastern regions, reflecting discontent. This highlights how historical and economic divisions continue to shape voter alignment decades after reunification.
Economic Status and Party Affiliation A scatterplot links income and education levels to party support. AfD draws support from lower-income, less-educated voters â€” similar to Trumpâ€™s base. Greens and FDP attract wealthier, more educated demographics. CDU and SPD are more broadly distributed but still reflect socioeconomic divides.
AfDâ€™s Rise and Fall A line graph tracks AfDâ€™s polling trajectory: The party rose sharply during the refugee crisis in 2015. It peaked around 15% in late 2016, then declined to about 10% by mid-2017. This trend aligns with reduced immigration levels and possible public reaction to global right-wing populism.
